zh.title: House Guide to Crazyhouse
zh.description:
__**ABOUT**__

#zh

**Crazyhouse** (ZH) is a chess variant in which an opponent's captured pieces can be dropped back on the board instead of moving a piece. Crazyhouse is a variant similar to bughouse chess, but with only two players.

Other names for this variant are drop chess, mad chess, reinforcement chess, turnabout chess and schizo-chess. It’s also known as wild 23. 

__**RULES**__

All the rules and conventions of standard chess apply, with the addition of drops, as explained below.

 • A captured piece reverses colour and goes to the capturing player's pocket. At any time, instead of making a move with a piece on the board, a player can drop a piece from their pocket onto an empty square on the board.
• Drops resulting in immediate checkmate are permitted.
• Pawns may not be dropped on the players' 1st or 8th ranks.
• Promoted but captured pawns are dropped as pawns.

Rules-page on lichess with video: https://lichess.org/variant/crazyhouse

__**WHERE?**__

● [lichess.org](https://lichess.org)
● [chess.com](https://chess.com)
● [Free Internet Chess Server](http://www.freechess.org/)
● [Internet Chess Club](https://www.chessclub.com/)

zh.title: House Guide to Crazyhouse
zh.description:
**__IMPROVE__**

Crazyhouse is a fast-paced game that needs strong tactics and a good awareness of positional weaknesses. Unlike regular chess, draws are rare because new pieces keep being reintroduced to the board. Check out [crosky’s crazyhouse overview](http://bit.ly/2FfYYMX).

• As GM Yasser Seirawan would say, **king safety** comes first and foremost. Ensure that your king's position is safe from attack; this does not necessarily imply castling – dropping pieces around your king can effectively guard it from serious threats.

• **Develop** your pieces in the opening and **control key squares**, especially around your king.

• Beware of **holes** in your position. A hole provides an opening for an opponent's piece which can lead to a strong attack. If pieces do enter, chase them away and secure your position. As helmsknight would say, “get out of my house!” Similarly, seek to exploit any holes your opponent leaves in their position.

• Beware of **piece sacs** on [f2/f7](https://youtu.be/kZPSNF8XHQI) or [g2/g7](https://youtu.be/6Gh2n9kWdb8), especially if the opponent has many pieces in hand.

• Often the best defence is **attack**, as any mating sequence threatened must be dealt; the majority of crazyhouse moves have an **attacking purpose**. As Vempele says, the best defence against @h3 might be @h6. Launch counter-attacks that are faster and cannot be ignored.

• **Initiative** is more important than material. If a player has initiative they can drop their pieces in hand with check and threats and dominate the board. It’s important to utilise positional dominance because if the initiative runs out, the opponent can take back initiative with pieces in hand and reassert control.

zh.title: House Guide to Crazyhouse
zh.description:
**__MATERIAL__**

• **Pawns** are more valuable than in regular chess, because they can be dropped anywhere on the board including the seventh rank. A minor pieces can be happily traded for 2 pawns in most situations. Unlike chess, **Doubled Pawns** are less of a weakness because pawn structures can be fixed with pawns in hand, and a doubled pawn can even be a strength because it controls squares of both colours. 

• **Knights** are wonderful attackers because their threats can’t be blocked [...].

• **Bishops** are strong defenders as they cover diagonals going backwards as well as forwards. A Bishop on g2, for instance, is able to take on h3 and still cover g2. They can also be good attackers because they control channels of a single colour. Pawns and Bishops are known as **"diags”** because they can penetrate an opponent position along diagonals of a single colour. If all your pawns are on light squares for example, you must take care to defend dark square weaknesses. For more on the importance of colour complexes, check out [mastertan’s visual guide](http://bit.ly/2FQmVZn).

• **Rooks** are useful to defend and attack open files. Dropping a rook on the back rank with check is a good way to force an opponent to “waste” a piece; combined with a pawn drop on the 7th exploiting the pin, this combination can have lethal effect. Rooks are often sacked on the backrank promoting a pawn to remove defenders. [Example](https://lichess.org/yUwqzUBO/black#27).

• **Queens** are worth less in crazyhouse than in normal chess, because they can be hit with a tempo by minors, especially when dropped. Crazyhouse favors numeracy in pieces; a Bishop and Knight in hand have more versatility than a Queen. In general, Queens are worth about 2 minors.

zh.title: House Guide to Crazyhouse
zh.description:
**__STRATEGY__**

• Crazyhouse is still chess, so **common chess tactics** still apply: try not to hang pieces or block in your own pieces; trap opponent pieces and use forks, pins and discovered checks. Because pieces can land anywhere on the board, one must be even more alert.

• **Defending**. Under heavy attack, it is important to evaluate your position. You usually have three options: **First**, you could take your opponent’s attackers, try to stay safe and hope the attack exhausts itself and they run out of material. You might try to limit the flow of exchanges to give time to get the king safe and not give pieces that the opponent needs to mate you. **Second**, if a sacrifice is too dangerous to take, you could focus on defending, dropping pieces near your king to cover important squares. One could also make luft, giving the king a flight path, or a safe square it can fall back or run up to. **The third option** is to ignore the threat and start an attack of your own: if you are the one getting to the opponent’s king first, go for it! Going all in can also be a last resort hoping your opponent makes a mistake.

• **Attacking**. To keep initiative, it is common for mating sequences to comprise purely of checks: [drawing the king out and/or cornering it](https://goo.gl/QLp4DY), [picking up pieces needed for mate](https://goo.gl/uNPKqG), [cutting off escape squares](https://goo.gl/2okT35), [luring the king to a mating square](https://goo.gl/Dd4BvF), [deflecting defending pieces](https://goo.gl/hX6Q85), and [opening up a file, diagonal or key square](https://goo.gl/AqLN86).

• It is important to be familiar with [common mating patterns](https://goo.gl/7ejioW).

zh.title: House Guide to Crazyhouse
zh.description:
**__VIDEOS__**

Streaming chess has become more popular in the past few years and crazyhouse has shared the fruits of this growing trend. The House presents to you the best and most famous streamers of crazyhouse.

• **JannLee**: [YouTube](<https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCbo8-5AEH7u3lE-yOGeNW1Q>), [Twitch](<https://www.twitch.tv/jannleecrazyhouse>).
• **Nikolas Theiss**: [YouTube](<https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCsjRN9g1AYODJZOPVJKzUmw/>), [Twitch](<https://www.twitch.tv/nikolastheiss>).
• **Thomas Crosky**: [YouTube](<https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCvowgcm56sLguWxYp8oqI1w>).
• **Helmsknight**: [YouTube](<https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCcKXwA_lo3Zpz3_Mc-WVLtw>), [Twitch](<https://www.twitch.tv/helmsknight>).
• **Okei**: [Twitch](<https://www.twitch.tv/okeizh>).
• **Mugwort**: [YouTube](https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCNMhNQybeLGJHWJv5qT1liQ), [Twitch](https://www.twitch.tv/mugwortcrazyhouse).

bug.title: House Guide to Bughouse
bug.description:
__**ABOUT**__

**Bughouse** (Bug) chess is a chess variant played on two chessboards by four players in teams of two. The game is usually played at a fast time control; this, together with the passing and dropping of pieces, can make the game look chaotic and random to the casual onlooker; hence the name bughouse, which is slang for mental hospital.

Bughouse chess is often called as its abbreviation bug. Other names for this variant are exchange chess, siamese chess, tandem chess, transfer chess, double bughouse, cross chess, swap chess or simply bughouse. It’s also known as wild 24.

__**RULES**__

Normal chess rules apply on bughouse, except that captured pieces on one board are passed on to the teammate on the other board, who then has the option of putting these pieces on his or her board. On any given move, you can either make a normal move, or "drop" a piece. You can only drop pieces that you have in hand, from your partner's captures.

__**WHERE?**__

Bughouse can be played on..

● [Free Internet Chess Server](http://www.freechess.org/)
● [bughousetest.com](http://bughousetest.com)
● [chess.com](http://chess.com)

Compiled by @MMichael#3973

bug.title: House Guide to Bughouse
bug.description:
__**IMPROVE **__

The guides on the next page will tell you extensively about bughouse strategies, this is only a brief foreword. According to my own experience, the most common novice mistakes are:

• Ignoring the **partner's board**: usually related to deciding whether to trade pieces or not.

• Not utilizing the **uptime**: the clocks are extremely important:  to avoid trades of certain pieces or to wait for certain pieces.

• Not **communicating**: it's very important to communicate with your partner, in some move the queen trade can be mating for you, in other move the trade can be fatal for you.

• Missing **in-between** moves: bishop fork checking the king and attacking a hanging piece is the most common.

• Giving up the **initiative/check**: if the clocks are even and both players are attacking each other, either giving checks or executing 1-move-threats are very useful in order to force your opponent on defensive foot.

bug.title: House Guide to Bughouse
bug.description:
__**GUIDES**__

Written guides by some of the most prolific bughouse players. View the next page to see training videos and advice.

• **Sorsi:** [Multiple blog posts](https://www.chess.com/blog/Sorsi)

• **Minigreat:** [Multiplie blog posts](https://www.chess.com/blog/MiniGreat)

• **420Blaziken_it:** [Bughouse concepts](http://bit.ly/2tempBu) about speed, efficiently, defending, activity, and looking at partner's board.

• **ChickenCrossRoad:** [Bughouse concepts](http://bit.ly/2F8FEly) about speed, communication,  move quality, material, and timing.

threecheck.title: House Guide to Three-Check
threecheck.description:
__**ABOUT**__

**Three-check** (3+) chess is a chess variant in which the winner is the first player to check their opponent three times. It’s also known as wild 25. 

__**RULES**__

All the normal chess rules apply, but one extra rule applies in addition:

• If you make a legal move that puts your opponent's king into third check for the third time in the game, you win.

A few clarifications to that rule exist as follows:

• The winning move has to be legal, i.e. you cannot give the third check while in check.
• Checkmating your opponent is still a legal way to win.
• A double check counts a single check towards the running total.

[Rules page on lichess.org](https://lichess.org/variant/threeCheck)

__**WHERE?**__

• [lichess.org](https://lichess.org)
• [chess.com](https://chess.com)
• [Free Internet Chess Server](http://www.freechess.org/)
• [Internet Chess Club](https://www.chessclub.com/)

You can simply type `... threecheck` followed by a number to navigate through our pages, alternatively:

`... threecheck improve` to see our strategy suggestions.
`... threecheck studies` to see a list of useful studies.
`... threecheck videos` to see some of the best 3-check video guides.

Compiled by MMichael#3973

footer.text: Page 1 of 4. "... threecheck improve" to see next page.

threecheck.title: House Guide to Three-Check
threecheck.description:
__**IMPROVE**__

Just as in chess, sacrifices are common and the opening can be filled with traps. Checking an opponent twice can create an advantage and can be equivalent to captured material in the evaluation of a position.

The theory has developed dramatically during the last year. Opening explorer on lichess will guide you regarding the theory, but remember that instead of memorizing the moves, you should figure out the meaning of each move.

[Three-check guide](https://www.chess.com/article/view/the-3-check-traps-you-need-to-know).

footer.text: Page 2 of 4. "... threecheck studies" to see next page.
Page 3 of 4. "... threecheck studies" to see next page.
Page 4 of 4. "... threecheck" to return to the introductory page.

anti.title: House Guide to Antichess
anti.description:
__**ABOUT**__

**Antichess** (anti) is a variant in which the aim  is to get rid of your own pieces. The game is also known as Losing chess, the Losing Game, Giveaway Chess, Suicide Chess, Killer Chess, Must-Kill, Take-All Chess, Capture Chess, Losums, or Take-Me. The game has recently been solved: there is a tree (called the Watkins tree) which proves a forced win for white from 1. e3. On the other other hand, many starting moves can lead to a forced loss for white which have been known throughout the history of the game, those include 1.e4, 1.d3 and 1.d4.

__**RULES**__

The rules follow most standard chess rules but demand in addition that **a capture is forced if it can be played**, if more then one capture is possible, then a player is permitted to choose which one to make. In mainstream anti the king is considered a normal piece and promotion to king is allowed and often useful. Victory is achieved by losing all the pieces or getting stalemated in standard rules. When playing on FICS, victory is awarded to the player with the smaller number of pieces on the board in the case of stalemate, and an equal number of pieces is considered to be a draw.

__**WHERE?**__

Antichess can be played on:

• [Free Internet Chess Server](http://www.freechess.org/)
• [lichess.org](https://lichess.org/)

You can simply type `... anti` followed by a number to navigate through our pages, alternatively:

`... anti pieces` to see the piece evaluations for antichess
`... anti basic` to see a list of beginner mistakes.
`... anti improve` to see tips on how to further.
`... anti guides` to see anti player's helpful resources.

Compiled by the-lone-wolf#4001

footer.text: Page 1 of 5. "... anti pieces" to see next page.

anti.title: House Guide to Antichess
anti.description:
**__PIECES__**

Details on each piece are given. Rough valuations are shown next to each piece name.

**KING** 0
+ The most important piece. You can waste moves to avoid zugzwang and solidate key areas.
- Too slow for other tasks.

**Queen** -1
+ Useful for middle-game tactics such as "Queen races", attacking opponents king and attacking weak squares.
- Dangerous in the endgame.

**Rook** -3
+ Quick endgame piece.
- Can easily turn into a "loose cannon".

**Bishop** -6
+ Good for early game tactics and drawing endgames due to opposite-colored bishops.
- Can easily turn into a "loose cannon".

**Knight** -5
+ Good for destroying pawn formations and forking weak squares.
- Immobile and bad in the endgame. Lose them before the endgame!

**Pawns** -1
+ Useful for restricting opponent's pieces and breaking pawn formations.
- Slow, immobile. Dangerous when it comes to forced promotions.

footer.text: Page 2 of 5. "... anti basic" to see next page.

anti.title: House Guide to Antichess
anti.description:
__**BASIC MISTAKES **__

Antichess is a very theoretical variant and there is lot of theory in it, especially cause of lines being often forced. Opening blunders are common between beginners, so safe openings such as **1. e3** are recommended. Losing openings for White include **1.a3, 1.b4, 1.c3, 1.d3, 1.d4, 1.e4, 1.f3, 1.f4, 1.h3, 1.h4, 1.Nc3** and **1.Nf3** but many of these are not trivial. Apart from 1. e3, other playable openings are **1.c4, 1.Nh3, 1.g3** (other openings are dubious). The most common novice mistakes are:

• Trying to **give away all pieces immediately** is therefore a mistake. One should carefully consider piece position; having more pieces that the opponent gives the ability to 'control' you, then give away all the pieces in one initiative.

• **Not developing.** Anti isn't really about giving away pieces in the beginning; one must develop pieces and make it harder for your opponent to move. That's a good strategy some of the really good players like to use, unless you have a forced win.

• Giving away **important** pieces: it is important to know which pieces to keep and which to give. Bishops are often dangerous, so it is recommended for beginners to get rid of bishops as soon as possible. On the other hand, the king is a precious ally when an opponent tries to zugzwang, giving it away early is often a mistake. It's better to keep pieces instead of pawns, because pawns have a very limited range of moves and can be easily predicted or forced into zugzwang.

• Being overly **passive**: simply trying to avoid exposing yourself to taking pieces lets an opponent 'control' you, then forcing you into zugzwang to take pieces. Carefully consider when one should trade and one should not.

footer.text: Page 3 of 5. "... anti improve" to see next page.

anti.title: House Guide to Antichess
anti.description:
__**FURTHER IMPROVE **__

Tips on how to advance your play:

• **Utilise choices**. Sometimes, it is advantageous to use one piece to take a piece in the opponent's position while your opponent is taking pieces; this can be referred to as a [queen race](https://lichess.org/0vDXr9aX). Be careful about attempting this with other pieces after: [In this game](https://lichess.org/study/SqCNKpVW), Black is out of bishop moves and must take White's queen, resulting in a loss. [Another example](https://lichess.org/study/2EjMqvsp).

• Be aware of so called quiet moves that can force your opponent **to take an unprotected piece**. [In this game](https://lichess.org/4FF1DBvW#4) an excellent example of such a move is 3. Bg2: preparing to take on b7, which will force Bxb7 and later Bxh1.

• Do **not** be too eager to **push the h- and a-pawns** as this exposes the rooks in mid-game. Rooks can be easily controlled and this can lead to a disastrous position if your opponent forces your rook into their position and is able to give away lots of material for nothing. On the other hand, if the opponent doesn't have a **b/g-pawn** pushing the a/h-pawn is often [a good move](https://lichess.org/study/e7IRQR1f).

footer.text: Page 4 of 5. "... anti guides" to see next page.

anti.title: House Guide to Antichess
anti.description:
**__GUIDES__**

Some useful antichess links:

• **Solved Tree**: [Mark Watkins](http://magma.maths.usyd.edu.au/~watkins/LOSING_CHESS/).

• **Finlip**: [YouTube](http://bit.ly/2Hj7Tuo), [Twitch](https://www.twitch.tv/anuppokhrel).

• **FKA_SooP**: [Introduction To Zugzwang](https://lichess.org/study/ad6RvpQb).

• **hauptschule**: [Facing 1. e3 as black](https://lichess.org/study/C2tvnF26).

• **John Beasley**: [Endgame tables: what ending pieces are winning?](http://bit.ly/2FpVkBa).

• **Frestho**: [Antichess tactics](https://lichess.org/study/WLrT4U2E)
  
Want your stream to appear here? Let the mods know.

horde.title: House Guide to Horde
horde.description:
__**ABOUT**__

**Horde chess** is a chess variant where the white side starts with 36 pawns (*The Pawns*) and the black side (*The Pieces*) needs to destroy the Horde to win. 

__**RULES**__

[Starting position](<https://i.imgur.com/Hurb8aW.png>)

The normal chess rules are valid; for example

• all pawns can be promoted on the final rank
• stalemate occurs, if either side run out of moves

The only exception is…

• that white's pawns on the first and second ranks may advance one or two steps, given that the path in the file is free. Unlike in regular chess, this does not have to be the pawn's first move.
• if a pawn advances two squares from the first to the third rank, black can not capture it with the enpassant rule

[Rules page on lichess](https://lichess.org/variant/horde).

__**WHERE?**__ 

● [Lichess.org](https://lichess.org/)

You can simply type `... horde` followed by a number to navigate through our pages, alternatively: 

`... horde improve` to see our strategy suggestions. 
`... horde studies` to see a list of useful studies. 
`... horde videos` to see some of the best horde videos.

footer.text: Page 1 of 4. "... horde improve" to see next page.

horde.title: House Guide to Horde
horde.description:
__**IMPROVE**__ 

**THE PAWNS**
White should keep their pawns **together** and promote.

The goal for white is to checkmate. This is most easily achieved after promotion (by which time black will probably resign after all of their sacrifices). White’s weakest files are **A- and H-files** since they are only defended once. White must guard these files and the backrank. White must remember that the power is in the horde, and therefore must not spreadout his pawns in an easily permeable, checker like structure. **Accept or reject** sacrifices as the position calls for. White must also keep in mind that should black get to the back of the horde, it's not always the end of the game. It takes valuable time for black to capture all of the pawns rank by rank -- time white could be using to promote pawns.

**THE PIECES** 
Black should target the rook files and get to the back ranks.

Winning with black is most easily achieved by getting to the back of the horde. The weakest files are A- and H-files, and therefore black should seek to **pressure** those files.

footer.text: Page 2 of 4. "... horde studies" to see next page.
Page 3 of 4. "... horde videos" to see next page.
Page 4 of 4. "... horde" to return to the introductory page.

atomic.title: House Guide to Atomic
atomic.description:
__**ABOUT**__ 

**Atomic chess** is a chess variant in which one has to nuke their opponent’s king in order to win the game.

It’s known as wild 27 or bomb chess.

__**RULES**__

The normal chess rules are valid, with the following extensions.

Whenever a piece is captured, an explosion occurs on the regarding field. The explosion destroys..
• the capturing piece
• the captured piece
• all pieces on the immediate horizontal, vertical and diagonal neighbour fields, except pawns. There is no chain reaction.

There are few more extra conditions compared to orthodox chess, those are:
• A game is won by checkmate or causing explosion of the opponent’s king by an indirect hit.
• Moves causing own king's explosion are not allowed. Any move that results in blowing up the opposite King will claim an immediate victory, overriding all checks.
• The kings can be connected by moving one into the adjacent squares of the other sided king. When the kings are connected, checks do not apply.

Rules-page on lichess: https://lichess.org/variant/atomic

__**WHERE?**__ 

● [Lichess.org](https://lichess.org/)
● [Free Internet Chess Server](http://www.freechess.org/)
● [Internet Chess Club](https://www.chessclub.com/).

You can simply type `... atomic` followed by a number to navigate through our pages, alternatively:

`... atomic improve` to see our material on how to improve.
`... atomic material` to see guides published by atomic players.

footer.text: Page 1 of 4. "... atomic improve" to see next page.

atomic.title: House Guide to Atomic
atomic.description:
__**IMPROVE**__

The knights, rooks, queens, bishops and pawns also develop their respective tactics in Atomic chess. Material sacrifices are more common in atomic chess than in chess. In the opening and middle-game it is common to offer a piece in order to seize an initiative enabled by the newly opened spaces captures create.

footer.text: Page 2 of 4. "... atomic studies" to see next page.

atomic.description:

schess.title: House Guide to Seirawan Chess
schess.description:
__**ABOUT**__

**Seirawan Chess (s-chess)** is a chess variant, which was invented by GM Yasser Seirawan and Bruce Harper 2007. It is played on the standard 8x8 board and uses two new pieces, **the hawk** (which moves like knight and bishop) and **the elephant** (which moves like knight and rook).

Seirawan chess is also known as Sharper chess (a combination of the names Seirawan and Harper). The idea of two extra pieces were adopted from the World Champons Jose Raoul Capablanca who in 1920s proposed **Capablanca chess**, adding two new pieces on a 10x10 board.

__**RULES**__ 

The rules are the same as in orthodox chess except that two pieces, the Elephant and the Hawk are placed in the reserve. Whenever a piece leaves its initial square, one of the extra pieces can be immediately be introduced to the vacant square. That means a player has eight opportunities to bring the Hawk and Elephant into play. If a player fails to do so, the unplaced piece remains out of play.

When a player castles, the Hawk or the Elephant may be placed on either e1(8) or h1(8)/a1(8), but not on both.

__**SITES**__

• [Schess.org](https://schess.org/#/).

You can simply type `... schess` followed by a number to navigate through our pages, alternatively: 

`... schess improve` to see our strategy suggestions. 
`... schess videos` to see some of the best s-chess videos.

footer.text: Page 1 of 3. "... schess improve" to see next page.

schess.description:
__**IMPROVE**__ 

The extra pieces give players more firepower, hence they make the game more tactical and deadly attacks occur more often than in orthodox chess.

footer.text: Page 2 of 3. "... schess videos" to see next page.

schess.description:
**__VIDEOS__**

**GMs Seirawan**, **Van Kampen** and **Hansen:** [Seirawan Chess Introduction](<https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=tSXZbbeR-kU>)

**IM Shahade** vs. **GM Seirawan:** [S-Chess match](<https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=97Jfv1U997M>)

footer.text: Page 3 of 3. "... schess" to return to the introductory page.

960.title: House Guide to Chess960
960.description:
__**ABOUT**__

**Chess960 (960)** is a chess variant, which uses the same board and pieces as orthodox chess, but the starting position of the pieces is randomized. However, the pieces on the both sides will be placed symmetrical. The random starting position is to hinder players from memorizing the opening lines and it forces them to rely more on their talent and creativity. 

Other names for this variant are Fischer Random Chess and **Fischerandom**, both named after Bobby Fischer, who invented the variant. It's also known as it’s also known as wild 22.

__**RULES**__ 

The rules are the same as in orthodox chess. However, the castling may seem different because the king and the rooks might have a different starting square than in standard chess.

[Rules page on lichess](<https://lichess.org/variant/chess960>).
         
__**SITES**__

● [lichess.org](https://lichess.org)
● [chess.com](https://chess.com)
● [Free Internet Chess Server](http://www.freechess.org/)
● [Internet Chess Club](https://www.chessclub.com/)

You can simply type `... 960` followed by a number to navigate through our pages, alternatively: 

`... 960 improve` to see our strategy suggestions. 
`... 960 videos` to see some of the 960 videos.

footer.text: Page 1 of 3. "... 960 improve" to see next page.

960.title: House Guide to Chess960
960.description:
__**IMPROVE**__

Now that you know the rules, you may wonder how to get better at Fischerandom. Since there are no opening theory, I would recommend to focus on these four points:

• Follow the normal opening **principles**: control center, develop your pieces and get your king in safety.
• Know your middlegame plans: identify **the weaknesses** in your and your opponent's camp, ask yourself how you can get rid of them and how you can exploit them.
• Be sharp with the **tactics**: It's been said that chess is 99% about tactics, you can work on your tactics in chesstempo or lichess. The tactical success requires an understanding of strategy.
• Master **the endgame**: Most of your 960 games will reach the endgame stage, be prepared to grind the victory in rook or other kind of endgames.

[How To Get Better At Chess article](<https://www.chess.com/article/view/how-to-get-better-at-chess>).

footer.text: Page 2 of 3. "... 960 videos" to see next page.

960.title: House Guide to Chess960
960.description:
**__VIDEOS__**

**IM John Batholomew:** [Chess960 introduction video](<https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=fUypgJQy7O8>)
**NM Chess-Network:** [10 ways to improve your chess](<https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=m--LuusPfwA>)

footer.text: Page 3 of 3. "... 960" to return to the introductory page.

koth.title: House Guide to King Of The Hill
koth.description:
__**ABOUT**__

**King of the Hill (KOTH)** is a chess variant, in which you win by checkmating your opponent or by bringing your king to the centre of the board.

__**RULES**__ 

The rules are the same as in orthodox chess with the addition of one simple rule:
• Move your king to one of the centre squares (d4, d5, e4 or e5) and you win.

The winning move must be legal, i.e. the king can’t move into check. Checkmating your opponent is also a legit way to win.

__**SITES**__

● [lichess.org](https://lichess.org)
● [chess.com](https://chess.com)

You can simply type `... koth` followed by a number to navigate through our pages, alternatively: 

`... koth improve` to see our strategy suggestions. 
`... koth videos` to see some of the 960 videos.

footer.text: Page 1 of 3. "... koth improve" to see next page.

koth.title: House Guide to King Of The Hill
koth.description:
__**IMPROVE**__

The additional rule tends to decoy novice players into running their king to the centre at the beginning of the game. This can be a fatal mistake as it may result in loss in development, material loss or checkmate on the running king.

footer.text: Page 2 of 3. "... koth videos" to see next page.

koth.title: House Guide to King Of The Hill

footer.text: Page 3 of 3. "... koth" to return to the introductory page.

racingkings.title: House Guide to Racing Kings
racingkings.description:
__**ABOUT**__

**Racing Kings (RK)** is a chess variant. The objective of the game is to move one’s own king to the last rank and do it faster than the opponent.

__**RULES**__ 

All pieces are positioned at the first two ranks and both players see the board from the same perspective. The starting position is [following](<https://i.imgur.com/sdnJ3Jz.png>).

Standard chess rules apply, with the following restrictions:

• It is not allowed to attack the opponent’s king. The concept of check is entirely forbidden.
• The king is not allowed to move to a square which is attacked by an opponent’s piece (just like in standard chess).

The game is finished if one player moves their own king to the last rank. However, if white moves his king to the last row, and black moves immediately that their king to the last rank, the game is draw (in order to compensate the fact that white player started the game.)

[Rules page on lichess](<https://lichess.org/variant/racingKings>).
         
__**SITES**__

● [Lichess.org](https://lichess.org/)

You can simply type `... racingkings` followed by a number to navigate through our pages, alternatively: 

`... racingkings improve` to see our strategy suggestions. 
`... racingkings videos` to see some of the best horde videos.

footer.text: Page 1 of 3. "... racingkings improve" to see next page.

racingkings.title: House Guide to Racing Kings
racingkings.description:
__**IMPROVE**__

This variant isn't studied widely, but some opening theory do exist. Tactics usually involve the fact that giving checks is not allowed, for example pieces may seem to be hanging, but they can't be captured because that would be a check to the enemy king.

footer.text: Page 2 of 3. "... racingkings videos" to see next page.
Page 3 of 3.  "... racingkings" to return to the introductory page.

dbpositions.title: House Database Positions
dbpositions.description:
Greetings! You may have noticed on your profile there's a little database number. That corresponds to your index in the bot's database. Being higher up in the db means:

• **Commands are slightly more likely to work for you.**

In addition to the other advantages:

**• Can be seen on the `.dblb`.
• Cool medal on your profile `!profile`.
• Better number.
• 'Higher' than everyone else.**

Basically, people with higher-up numbers are just *better*. How do you change your position?

fields.name: 1. Bid an Amount and Win
fields.value:
You can bid for a position using:

`.give [bid amount] theLAZYmd#2353 Database Position [desired position]`

For example:

`.give 100 theLAZYmd#2353 Database Position 1`

The amount you give is saved as your 'bid amount.' Using the command challenges another member for their position in the database. If your total bid amount is greater than their bid amount in reserver (consolidated) your challenge will be successful and you will take their position.

fields.name: 2. Bid an Amount and Attack
fields.value: You can also underbid. If your total bid is lower than their consolidated bidamount, your bid will be used to cancel out their sum and that's it.

fields.name: 3. Consolidate
fields.value:
You should therefore secure your position by consolidating your position. Do that by:

`.give 100 theLAZYmd#2353 Database Consolidate`

Check anyone's consolidated amounts by `!bidamount [user]`, `!position [user]`, and `.dblb`.

typeadd.title: Conditions for an accepted Type Entry
typeadd.description:
**Example**:
`.typeadd And is he likely to be brave who has no spirit, whether horse or dog or any other animal? Have you never observed how invincible and unconquerable is spirit and how the presence of it makes the soul of any creature to be absolutely fearless and indomitable? Then we have found the desired natures. -The Republic`

footer.text: Plz come up with interesting stuff!

fields.name: Body Text
fields.value:
• Must be between 265 and 529 characters long.
• Cannot contain not latin alphabet characters.
• Cannot contain line breaks or tabs.

fields.name: Source
fields.value:
•Must be included!
• Comes after the Body Text.
• Is introduced by a "-"
• Should contain author or source book/movie/media.

fields.name: What happens next
fields.value:
• Entry is submitted to mods.
• We approve it by pressing a button and immediately grant you flowers.
• Anything that passes those conditions that is not inappropriate will be accepted.

join.content: **Welcome to The House %user.mention%!** Let's get the party started <@&420314782114250761>.
join.description: **We're the home of chess variants across lichess.org, chess.com, FICS, and anywhere else.**

footer.text: Have fun!

fields.name: View our channels
fields.value:
You won't be able to see most of our channels until you're a **Member.**
Firstly, familiarise yourself with the rules in <#390259315816005644>.
Then, head to <#404374157045006346> and assign yourself permissions to see the chat channels and your favourite variant channels.

fields.name: How the hell do I use Discord?
fields.value: First time? type `... discord` for our guide on navigating this place.

fields.name: Link your accounts
fields.value:
Type `!lichess` followed by your account name.
Type `!chess.com` followed by your account name.

fields.name: Crazyhouse World Championships
fields.value: Type `.iam CWC` to see the CWC channels on the left.

fields.name: Developers
fields.value: If you're a dev, type `@mods I'm a dev` and you'll be added to <#408363007635226625>.

tournamentreward.title: House Server Tournament Rewards
tournamentreward.description:
Create a tournament on lichess.org in any variant or time control of chess! Include the words House Discord Server in the title as well as the variant name and the link https://discord.gg/RhWgzcC in the chatbox at the beginning and end of the tournament to get reward.

Reward is based on tournament participation. We estimate participation by a function of number of games `[n]` and time control of the tournament `[t]` and increment `[i]` both in minutes. This data is available once the tournament finishes.

Tournament hosters must play for at least half the time. The aim of this initiative is to encourage people to play and learn variants! So please make sure you participate and enjoy the tournaments.

fields.name: Bonuses
fields.value: 2x 🌸 for any Atomic arena, and 1.25x for any other variant with a sparsely populated channel. An additional 20 🌸 per person who joins and adds roles.

fields.name: The formula is as follows (copy and paste):
fields.value:
`.tf games time increment`

A tournament with 120 games played of 3+2 time control would be
`.tf 120 3 2`

flowers.title: What are flowers?
flowers.description:
Flowers are the artificial currency we use on this Discord server. We use them for fun purposes, like betting on tournaments and challenging each other to achieve things.

Obviously it doesn't mean anything, but it's fun, and those who have lots are the best.

fields.name: Invite people to the server
fields.value: Inviting someone to the server nets 20 🌸! This is often best done through DMs on lichess or posting in tournament or game chats. Invite your opponents after long match series! The larger the community we build here the better this place becomes. Bonus 🌸 for inviting through tournaments.

fields.name: Create a House tournament
fields.value: Hugely popular - create a tournament on lichess and we'll sponsor you 🌸! Type `... challenge` or `... tournament` for details.

fields.name: Do something impressive
fields.value: Get a a FIDE title; win a big Lichess shield or tournament; beat out some folk in a Titled Tuesday arena... let us know and we might dish out 🌸 for anything that sounds vaguely impressive.

fields.name: Complete a challenge
fields.value: Listed in <#406161920308150272>. Ask someone to give you a challenge like reaching a high rating or high position in a tournament. The server might offer extremely high payouts on certain events.

fields.name: Leave us a great quote
fields.value: We're looking for quotes to add to our typecontest game. Have a look at the criteria in `... typeadd` then leave us a quote. If we approve it you'll earn 🌸.

flowers.title: How can I get free flowers?

fields.name: React with 🌸 when there's an event
fields.value: Every now and then, theLAZYmd#2353 will create an event that gives out free flowers in <#390264166843154433>. Simply react with 🌸 to the message to get them, so check <#390264166843154433> frequently!

fields.name: Pick 🌸 when they appear in a text channel
fields.value: Everyone message has a 2% of generating 🌸. Type `.pick` as they appear, alternatively people might type `.plant` to drop them for you.

fields.name: Collect `.timely` periodically
fields.value: You may collect 2 🌸 every 2 hours from <#390273555084083210> using the command `.timely`

fields.name: Win Trivia games
fields.value: The House's speciality game - trivia contests between its highly competetive members! Play at any time in <#390289422802747403> by typing `.t`, the first to 10 wins. Bigger and better games win more 🌸! `... tr` to see the rewards.

flowers.title: How can I get even more flowers?
flowers.description: You need to risk 🌸 to get 🌸. Here's some of the ways you can do that:

fields.name: Betting
fields.value: The hallmark of this server - you can place bets on your friends and favourites playing matches and tournaments. Odds are offered by our @licensed bookies, become one simply by asking! Bookies will give odds on certain outcomes of those tournaments and matches, you can choose one to invest in, with the hope of a high return. See `...howtobet` for more information.

fields.name: Gambling
fields.value: For the truly adventurous - gamble away your savings in our bot's in-built casino. Head to <#390259390709497857> and type `.commands gambling` to see what you can play. The list of commands is also written up in the **GAMBLING** section of <#390259315816005644>.

manageembeds.title: LAZY guide on how to use embeds (if you need to keep editing/if you're doing complicated stuff)

footer.text: ~By the goodwill of theLAZYmd#2353 who struggled hard with embeds to come up with a method. DM him if you need help.

fields.name: Left Side
fields.value: Create an 'embed channel'. Here, have the bot post your embeds you've created through `... embedex` using the `.say` command.

fields.name: Right Side
fields.value: Create a 'markdown channel'. Here, post each markdown in codeblock form, and type `.edit [comment id]` before it, where the comment id corresponds to the embed in the embed channel.

fields.name: Making Edits
fields.value: Now it's super-easy: change things in the markdown, then simply highlight and copy over the markdown *including* the `.edit [comment id]` text over the a new comment in the embed channel. No more worries about resizing, or going over the character limit. Everything is as you see it.

fields.name: Publishing your Embeds
fields.value: Ok when you're done, just copy your final codeblock from your markdown page, and stick `.acr triggerword {embed business]` or `.. triggerword {embed business]` You'll have a perfect thing, and you'll never need to use `.qdel` ever again!

bughousetest.title: **Bughousetest.com - bughouse on lichess interface!**
bughousetest.description:
**General**
Bughousetest.com is a fork of lichess made by <@335877728945569792>. He forked lichess and implemented bughouse in it. It is **not** affiliated with lichess, therefore you have to **register** before playing. It is not recommended to use the same password.

**Features**
• Double-click or shift-click on pieces in hand to request piece.
• Double-click or shift-click on pieces in opponent's hand to forbid.
• Suggest a move to your partner by making a move on their board.
• Use go/sit buttons to send the respective messages to partner.
• __Partnering__: click the partner button on any player's profile.
• Diagram: https://i.imgur.com/Etowg4U.png.

**Weekly Bughouse Tournament**
• A weekly tournament is played __Sundays at 3 p.m. EST / 8 p.m. UTC.__
• <@&390258769067638784> role will be pinged when the tournament is about to start. Enable Discord notifications if you want to be notified.

**Feedback**
Have any bug reports, feature requests or suggestions? Please let us know in <#391347094574727168>. Suggested features are voted upon in <#391347045023350784>.

cvt.title: Chessvariants.training - The promised land of chess variant puzzles.
cvt.description:
**Puzzles**
For years the chess community has been asking leading sites to add variant compatability to their tactics platforms, which never came to fruition, until now. Being the first of its kind, [chessvariants.training](https://chessvariants.training/) was created and is run by <@163325840136863744>. You can solve antichess, atomic, crazyhouse, king of the hill, three-check, horde, and racing kings puzzles, respectively.

**Variant960**
In addition to its tactics trainer, the site also offers Variant960 games, which can be played [here](https://chessvariants.training/Variant960).

shop.title: Official House Shop Roles
shop.description:
Congrats on accumulating a whole bunch of flowers. Here are the roles you can buy; they will give you a special color flair and make you superior to other members on the right sidebar! The colors look really nice.

Check savings by `.$`. Check level by `.xp`

__Bronze__: 200 🌸; **if level 5**, 90 🌸
__Silver__: 360 🌸; **if level 10**, 180 🌸 
__Gold__: 680 🌸; **if level 20**, 370 🌸 
__Diamond__: 1320 🌸; **if level 30**, 760 🌸 

Are you just that special that you want your own color? Well then buy:

__ChooseColor__: 500 🌸 

That makes your color whatever you want it to be by using the `!color` command. However, it does not affect your right sidebar standings; it's for the vain ones among us.

footer.text: Role rewards must be bought in order.

ticket.title: Claim your flowers
ticket.description:
Type `.ticket add [flowers] [reason]` to claim your 🌸.
• If you claim 🌸 for a tournament please add the link to the tournament
• If you claim for a match add timecontrol, number of games and the link of the first game
• If you claim for inviting a user plug in his name as a reason

footer.text: Use `... tournament` if you need to calculate the amount first.

fields.name: Example
fields.value: `.ticket add 31 for this tournament https://lichess.org/tournament/4ihC4TfT`

trivia.title: House Trivia
trivia.description: Based on **number of participants** in the trivia game! Bigger rewards, more features for better games.

fields.name: Winnings
fields.value:
**1** player: 0 🌸 for 1st
**2** players: 3 🌸 for 1st, 1 🌸 for 2nd
**3** players: 4 🌸 for 1st, 2 🌸 for 2nd
**4** players: 5 🌸 for 1st, 3 🌸 for 2nd, 1 🌸 for 3rd
**5** players 6 🌸 for 1st, 4 🌸 for 2nd, 2 🌸 for 3rd
**6 players** 7 🌸 for 1st, 5 🌸 for 2nd, 3 🌸 for 3rd, 1 🌸 for 4th
... and so on.

Payouts are done automatically.
Pokemon trivia is not rewarded 🌸.

fields.name: Rating
fields.value: Trivia games are now rated using a formula and mechanism developed by @ObiWanBenoni and @TcubesAK respectively! More info to come...

greet.content: **Welcome to The House %user.mention%!** Let's get the party started @welcome squad.
greet.description:
**Bienvenue à "Chez Nous"!** C'est une plateforme géniale pour discuter les variantes d'échecs de lichess.org, chess.com, FICS, et n'importe où.

Vous ne pouvez pas voir et utiliser la majorité de salons de chat avant s'inscrire comme un Membre. Pour faire ça, après avoir lu les règles dans #welcome, allez à #role-assignment et lisez les instructions. Réagissez avec les emojis appropriés pour gagner l'accès aux salons.

Si vous êtes en général plus confortables en parlant français, écrivez `.atl fr>en` pour faire traduire au bot automatiquement vos phrases.

greet.content: **Welcome to The House %user.mention%!** Let's get the party started @welcome squad.
greet.description:
**Willkommen in "The House"!** Wir sind dein Zuhause für Schachvarianten auf lichess.org, chess.com , FICS und an allen anderen Orten.

Die meisten Kanäle werden für dich unsichtbar sein, solange du noch kein **Mitglied**bist. Wenn du die Regeln in #welcome durchgelesen hast, gehe bitte zu #role-assignment und weise dir die Berechtigungen zu, sodass du die Chat- und Varianten-Kanäle sehen kannst.

Falls du nicht so gut mit English klarkommst, schreibe `.atl de>en`, um deine Nachrichten automatisch übersetzen zu lassen.

greet.content: **Welcome to The House %user.mention%!** Let's get the party started @welcome squad.
greet.description:
**Bienvenidos a "Nuestra Casa"!** Aquí podrás discutir los variantes de ajedrez de lichess.org, chess.com, FICS y otros sitios.

La mayoría de los canales aquí solo se pueden ver si eres un **Miembro.** Cuando te has familiarizado con las reglas en #welcome, por favor, ven a #role-assignment para asignarte unas roles y ver los canales de chat y los canales de tus variantes favoritos.

Si prefirirías hablar español, escriba `.atl es>en` para que el bot traduzca automáticamenta lo que escribes.

greet.content: **Welcome to The House %user.mention%!** Let's get the party started @welcome squad.
greet.description:
**Benvenuto in "The House!"** Questa è la casa di tutte le varianti degli scacchi presenti su lichess.org, chess.com, FICS e in qualsiasi altro luogo.

Non potrai vedere o usare molti dei nostri canali finchè non sarai un Membro degli stessi. Dopo aver  preso visione delle regole in #welcome, entra in #role-assignment e conferisciti i permessi per vedere le chat e i canali delle tue varianti preferite.

Se in generale vi trovate più a vostro agio nel parlare Italiano, digitate `.atl it>en` così che il bot traduca automaticamente le vostre frasi.

guides.title: How to edit an Official™ House Discord Guide
guides.description:
Head to [this url](https://github.com/theLAZYmd/LAZYbot/edit/master/src/data/embeds.json) which is the bot's **GitHub Repo**.
Scroll down to the section of the data relevant to you. You can do that by viewing the `"title`" of each embed and making the correlation to the title you're looking for, or `Ctrl+F`-ing a suitable word or phrase that will help you identify it.

fields.name: 1. Edit the JSON for that embed.
fields.value:
If it's a minor correction, this shouldn't be an issue, just add it in the change required. If you're doing something more complicated, or you don't understyand what's going on here, have a look at [this article](https://www.red-gate.com/simple-talk/sql/oracle/json-for-absolute-beginners-part-1-introduction/) or ask someone in #devs for help.
Switch to the `soft-wrap` mode in the top right of the editing box if that makes things easier.

fields.name: 2. Submit the Pull Request.
fields.value:
Scroll down to the bottom.
Write a one-line description for what you've done to the file in the 'Update embeds.json' field, then write a more detailed description below if necessary.
Press `Propose file change`! When the next page loads up, click `Create Pull Request` whenever it appears. 
We'll review what you've done and correct it if necessary before approving! As soon as your changes are approved their live on the bot!

events.title: HOUSE EVENT - TRIVIA CHAMPIONSHIP
events.description:
Yeah, you read that right. We're going to do a tournament of your favourite server game, and crown one of you the **TRIVIA CHAMPION** of the {year/month/week/season/depends on how I'm feeling}.

Here's how it works:

footer.text: Best of luck!

fields.name: QUALIFIERS
fields.value: Monday to Thursday. 9pm UTC **EVERY DAY** qualifiers. Rules are simple: at 8.30pm UTC exactly, trivia will be disabled, then at 9pm, lazy will type `.trivia 20`. A 20-question game of trivia will be played. **Win one of those qualifiers**... to qualify.

fields.name: SEMIFINALS
fields.value: Friday. 9PM UTC. Semi-Finals. The 4 semifinalists are seeded, and #1 seed plays #4 and #2 plays #3. Winner goes through to Finals. 10-question trivia, best of 5.

fields.name: 3RD AND 4TH PLAYOFF
fields.value: Saturday. 9PM UTC. The two losers from the semifinals play a series of 5. 10-question trivia. Winner gets 3rd place and is awarded 20 :cherry_blossom:, loser get's 4th and is awarded 10 :cherry_blossom:.

fields.name: FINALS
fields.value: Sunday. 7PM UTC. Series of 5, 10-question trivia. Loser wins 2nd place and 30 :cherry_blossom:. Winner gets title of **HOUSE TRIVIA CHAMPION** (new role) and 50 :cherry_blossom:.

events.title: HOUSE EVENT - SHIELDS
events.description:
Alright, same deal as last time, good luck in those Shield Arenas.
​

footer.text: Best of luck!

fields.name: SHIELDS
fields.value: Win a lichess shield! Head [here](https://lichess.org/tournament/calendar) to see the dates of the shield. Win 1 to be awarded VIP role + 50 :cherry_blossom:. Payouts for high performers too.

fields.name: Rankings
fields.value:
Top 30 win 10 :cherry_blossom:
Top 20 win 20 :cherry_blossom:
Top 10 win 30 :cherry_blossom:
Top 3 win 40 :cherry_blossom:

cwc.title: Entrant Eligibility
cwc.description:
Entrants who meet the following criteria will be accepted automatically:

**1.** Have an established crazyhouse rating on lichess.

**2.** Have played at least 50 rated crazyhouse games on lichess.

**3.** Have had an account on lichess for over 1 month at the time of entry.

**4.** Be participating only using their main account (no dupe accounts).

**5.** Have messaged the TD (FischyVishy) with intent to join **within** the entry period.

**6.** Have joined the Crazyhouse World Championship group.

Points 1, 2 and 3 above are aimed primarily at preventing duplicate accounts from entering. Entries not meeting these criteria may still be accepted and seeded at the TD's discretion.

Exceptions are most likely to be made for players known within the crazyhouse community who clearly are not using duplicate accounts.

Any player attempting to use multiple accounts or computer assistance will be kicked out and if necessary reported to lichess moderators.

cwc.title: Knockout Tournament Rules I
cwc.description:
You will be paired with a player for a round. There will be a week for you to play your round in, with a week in between rounds as breaks / negotiation periods. Please note the following stipulations:

**1.** It is preferable if the games are rated. If **both** players agree then some or all games can be unrated.

**2.** Results **and** games of each match should be messaged to the TD upon completion.

**3.** All matches will consist of an equal number of White games per player.

**4.** Each match will consist of ten (10) games of 3 + 2.

**5.** If the score is 5-5 after 10 games then the tie-break will consist of games of 3 + 2, until one player is ahead after an even number of games.

**6.** Either player can stop the match if someone reaches 5.5 points in the first 10 games, as long as the player stopping the match has not played more rated White games than their opponent.

**7.** Each player is entitled to a short break of approximately 10 minutes after every 2 games (these breaks can be accumulated).

**8.** The tournament main draw will have 128 players. If the number of entrants is not equal to 128 players, a qualification tournament will be held. The x number of top-finishers from said tournament will get a spot in the knockouts.

cwc.title: Knockout Tournament Rules II
cwc.description:
**9.** Assuming there are 128 players, after the first round there will be 64 players left and so on until there are 8 players left.

**10.** The initial pairing will have the top seed vs. bottom seed, the second seed vs. second from bottom, etc. For example, in an eight player event: (1) vs. (8), (2) vs. (7), (3) vs. (6), (4) vs. (5). The winner of (1) vs. (8) will then play the winner of (4) vs. (5) and the winner of (2) vs. (7) will play the winner of (3) vs. (6). The winner of those matches would then contest the "final" (before the Candidates).(edited)

**11.** The seeding will be based on the average between a player’s current rating and highest rating at the time their entry is received & logged.

**12.** If somebody is unable to complete a series, or has to withdraw, their opponent is considered the victor. Only emergencies can exempt players from having this rule applied to them. Byes may be issued in the case of an odd number of players.

**13.** If someone knows they will not be able to play a certain week when a round is scheduled, they must notify the TD before they play their prior match. At the TD's discretion their match may be moved to the following week. This will only occur a maximum of one time per player.

**14.** After each match, players will typically have at least a week's rest until the next match. A possible exception is when a player has notified the TD of their unavailability (point 13).

**15.** Once the knockout tournament cuts down the number of players to 8, a candidates tournament will take place.

cwc.title: Candidates Tournament Rules
cwc.description:
The candidates tournament will be a round robin event. Each player will play each of the other seven players in a 3 + 2 match similar to those matches of the knockout tournament stage. Thus, each player will play 90 games in the Candidates. The playing period of these matches will extend for two weeks. The winner of the candidates tournament will challenge the world champion ([JannLee](https://lichess.org/@/JannLee)) for a shot at the crazyhouse title.

**1.** It is preferable if the games are rated. If **both** players agree then some or all games can be unrated.

**2.** Results **and** games of each match should be messaged to the TD upon completion.

**3.** All matches will consist of an equal number of White games per player.

**4.** Each match will consist of ten (10) games of 3 + 2.

**5.** Do note that there are no tie breaks and the matches cannot be stopped if a player reaches 5.5. Only in case of a tie after all 90 games will tiebreak rules apply (the tiebreaks are the same as those of the knockout tournament stage).

**6.** Each player is entitled to a short break of 10 minutes after every 2 games (these breaks can be accumulated).

**7.** If somebody is unable to complete a series, or has to withdraw, their opponent is considered the victor. Only emergencies can exempt players from having this rule applied to them.

**8.** One candidates spot is reserved for last year's challenger to the crown ([TwelveTeen](https://lichess.org/@/TwelveTeen)) and another is reserved for a wild card ([opperwezen](https://lichess.org/@/opperwezen), third place in last year's Candidates). There will be 8 participants from the knockout event, so the number of Candidates tournament participants is 10 players.

cwc.title: Match Negotiations
cwc.description:
**1.** Players may begin negotiating a playing start time as soon as their next pairing is known.

**2.** Each player is responsible to offer at least three separate times for the match, during the rest week, unless an offer has been accepted before that number is reached.

**3.** The three offered times should be no closer than three hours to each other and no more than two on a single date.

**4.** If three offers are not made in time, the player at fault must accept a time chosen by the opponent.

**5.** If both players fail to make three offers by the deadline, a match arbiter will assign a time.

**6.** A player should respond to an offer by accepting or making a different offer, preferably within 24 hours.

**7.** If a player is excessively or repeatedly late for scheduled matches, they may be forfeited.

**8.** If both players make three offers but no agreement is made before the playing week begins, a match arbiter will determine if fault lies with a particular player.

**9.** If a player is at fault, their opponent will decide the match time; if no player is at fault, the match arbiter will assign a match time.

cwc.title: World Championship Rules
cwc.description:
The world championship will be played in a three-week period. In each week, two 10-game 3 + 2 matches will take place. The first player to reach 30.5 / 60 will be declared the winner. Please note the following stipulations:

**1.** It is preferable if the games are rated. If **both** players agree then some or all games can be unrated.

**2.** Results **and** games of each match should be messaged to the TD upon completion.

**3.** All matches will consist of an equal number of White games per player.

**4.** Each match will consist of ten (10) games of 3 + 2.

**5.** Each player is entitled to a short break after every 2 games of approximately 10 minutes (these breaks can be accumulated).

**6.** If somebody is unable to complete a series, or has to withdraw, their opponent is considered the victor. Only emergencies can exempt players from having this rule applied to them.

**7.** Note that the final of the Crazyhouse World Championship will be played during three consecutive weeks – there will be no rest weeks.

cwc.title: Reporting Cheaters
cwc.description:
**1.** Accusations of cheating must be made privately to a member of the anti-cheating panel.

**2.** The accusation must make reference to at least one specific game.

**3.** If an accusation is made publicly and does not lead to a guilty verdict, the accuser will be forfeited & banned from future events.

**4.** The anti-cheating panel will consist of five members.

**5.** The anti-cheating panel must all believe a player to be guilty 5-0 for a player to be forfeited. 100% proof is not required.

**6.** If a member of the panel is either the accuser or accused, their place on the panel will be taken by a substitute.

games.title: Welcome to grindroll. Here are the rules.
games.description:
• Start with `.give x @grindonmygrande`
• Roll 2 dice using `.roll 2`  
  
• If you roll a **2,3,4,9,10,11,12** you win!
• Payout **2x** for **3,4,9,10,11**
• Payout **3x** for **2,12**
  
Wait for @Grindonmygrande#6203 to be online.

games.title: Rules of Music Flip & Roll
games.description:
1. Start by typing`.give x @Musickn`
2. Flip 30 using `.roll 30`.
3. If your average is lower than **2.85 or higher** than an average of **4.05**, then you get to flip a coin. Call **heads** or **tails**. If you win the coin flip, then you get **3x** what you bet!
4. If your average is lower than **3.45**, then you get to flip a coin. Call **heads** or **tails**. If you win the coin flip you, then get **2x** what you bet!
5. If your average is lower than **3.55**, then you get to flip a coin. Call **heads** or **tails**. If you win the coin flip, then you get **1.5x** what you bet!

Flip by using `.flip`.
Have fun!

games.title: Welcome to LAZYflip. Here are the rules to the game.
games.description:
• Start with `.give x @theLAZYmd n`, where n is the length of the game 'first to what'
• Continuously flip a coin using `.flip`

• If you get **2 heads in a row** you get a point!
• If you get a Heads followed by a Tails, LAZY gets a point.

• The first to **3** points wins.
• If you win, you get **2x** payout!
• You cannot use the same coin two different points.  
  
If you wish you can set the game to be longer, please specify the 'first to' parameter in the original message. Minimum length 3.

footer.text: Good luck!

bet.title: How to Bet
bet.description:
To place your bet you need to give the bet amount `.give [x] @[bookie] [outcome]` to the bookie that is offering odds.
Replace [x] with the bet amount and [bookie] with the username of the bookmaker.
Also don't forget to tell which outcome you want by replacing [outcome].

**How to get odds**
Bookies offer odds for various occasions.
Always check the #betting channel where new odds will be released.
Make sure to place your bet before the odds expire (if an expiration time is given).
@theLAZYmd#2353  offers odds for trivia matches between players on this server.
@ObiWanBenoni#3488  offers bets on lichess tournaments.
@Grindonmygrande#6203 offers odds on sports like NFL/NBA.
@sibirica  offers odds occasionally as well.
Offering bets is only allowed for @licenced bookie .

**What do the odds numbers mean?**
The odds work like a multiplicator. If you win your bet you earn the bet amount multiplied by the number.
Example:
Bet Amount 10 :cherry_blossom:, Odds: 2.0
If you win your bet you get 2*10=20 :cherry_blossom:.
If you lose you won't get any flowers back.

**How can I see that my bet was accepted?**
Once your bet appears in the #bet-log channel it was officialy accepted.

**How can I claim refund?**
Betting is at your own risk so in general there are no refunds.
If you bet on a player that is caught cheating or stops playing in the tournament suddenly it remains your problem.

bet.title: Get your match hosted by ObiBets
bet.description:
**How to get odds**

Tell me:
• Your usernames (on lichess etc.)
• Variant
• Type of match (see below)
• Number of games
• Timecontrol
• Date and time of your match

And pay the 5 🌸 fee for creating odds.
I will create odds then and announce the match.

**Requirements**

• Stable ratings
• The rating difference between both participants should be lower than 150 pts.

**Match Conditions**

*Match with a total number of games (preferred)*
The match finishes after you reached the specified number of decisive games.
Betting on a tie is possible if you use an even number of games. If you want to have a decisive match result use an odd number.
Draws do not count to the match score.

**Further rules**

*Match reward*
The server sponsors matches as well. The reward is not depending on the outcome of the match.
Type `...matchreward` for more details.

*Betting*
Participants of the match are only allowed to bet on themselves winning. They can't bet on a tie or exact outcomes.
If you don't know how betting works type `... howtobet`.
